abstract: Paradoxically, an increase in competition among insurers may lead to higher reimbursements and health care spending, and thus higher premiums, particularly when the medical provider market is not very competitive, three economists write.
snippet: Paradoxically, an increase in competition among insurers may lead to higher reimbursements and health care spending, and thus higher premiums, particularly when the medical provider market is not very competitive, three economists write.
lead_paragraph: Dana P. Goldman is the director of the Leonard D. Schaeffer Center for Health Policy and Economics at the University of Southern California. Michael Chernew and Anupam Jena are professors of health care policy at Harvard University.

headline.main: Health Insurance Exchanges May Be Too Small to Succeed

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

byline.original: By Dana P. Goldman, Michael Chernew and Anupam Jena
